cab.content: Whitehall Gardens, S..W, March 13th, 1922. CTH^S- DOCUM'NT IS TPE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT)-.^5212* C A B I N E T.CjJ&z^3831. A GREEK ;WARSHIP AT CYPRUS. Paraphrase Telegram from the High Commissioner of Cyprus to the Secretory of State for the Colonies. Dated 9th March, 1922. (Received Colonial Office 8.15 aam0 ioth March,1922) (Circulated by the Secretary of State for the Colonies). A Greek Warship named IERAX anchored on the afternoon of March 9th off Cape ANDREAS, where despite the Customs Officer's protests an officer and man forced a landinga The Customs Officer at Cape Andreas told the Greek officer that they could not be permitted in view of instructions which he had received to land there but if they required anything must proceed to Pamagusta the nearest port, fifty miles distant^ The Greek officer replied that he insisted upon landing. He landed and proceeded to the monastery where he had a hurried Interview In secret with the ABBOT and subsequently departed. Against this violation of the law and territory of Cyprus by an armed ship of war I must protest in the strongest manner of which I am capable and I urge immediate steps be taken to secure from the Greek Govern- ment the fullest satisfaction for this occurrence. STEVENSON.
